posts.cooked: Hey guys, my team is currently trying to implement shooting on the fly but I have no idea how to do it. Any suggestions, resources, ideas that might help me? Thanks in advance!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: By ‚Äúshooting on the fly‚Äù do you mean shooting while moving/driving?

posts.name: Chase Vendrillo
posts.cooked: Well this could be a programming thing or something the driver does or both, the real question is do you have swerve or a turret? If you don‚Äôt have either well I don‚Äôt know how much shooting on the fly will help. If you have a turret then its entirely programming, I don‚Äôt have experience working with turrets nor does my team to advice you on that, I‚Äôm sure others definitely have resources on that. If you‚Äôre on swerve this could be a programming thing, where like with a turret I‚Äôd assume you‚Äôd use pose estimation and some things to attempt to predict the pose the shooter will be shooting at to try and predict your location so you can shoot while move. But I know programming at a rudimentary level so I can‚Äôt help with that. However, I can say in the WCP competitive concept reveal video of this year ( https://youtu.be/TKs_UDj4Ej0?t=53 like 00:53 is a good place to start), they shoot on the move where it doesn‚Äôt seem like they use vision software. So you could for the simplest form of shoot while moving have drivers do most of the work. You could have a button to slow down the drivebase for more control but so you can still move (if you want), use polar locking I think its called to be straight on to the speaker (if you want) and have the drivers shoot at a certain point the path they drive. This is the easiest way to shoot while moving without heavy programming stuff. You could also use whatever autoaiming and slow down your drivebase to probably be able to shoot while moving. But I think there are simple and intermediate ways to shoot while move with some programming accommodations and driver practice which I‚Äôd recommend unless you have a large programming team and a lot of time before competition, if you want to get more complex then I have less direct advice but you could definitely scour conversations that have already been on here. If you need a visual of what I was talking about or a better explanation of something I can clarify.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Either way it‚Äôs purely software. Even if you don‚Äôt have a turret, and just a omnidirectional drive, the entire drivetrain can act as a ‚Äúvirtual turret‚Äù so to speak, and rotate the robot such that it is locked on target, just as a turret might do.

We‚Äôve done this in our codebase.

posts.name: Chase Vendrillo
posts.cooked: Yeah the method is similar for turret and swerve, and a drive train that can turn can auto aim, swerve can just do it while moving (I might‚Äôve been confusing but I said ‚Äúwhere like with a turret‚Äù meaning the methods are somewhat similar in terms of prediction), but drivers can make up for where their programming capabilities potentially couldn‚Äôt, especially with some quality of life programming that is simpler than shooting on the fly.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
viggy96:

We‚Äôve done this in our codebase.

Is your code public? We‚Äôd love to take a look

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Yes it is.

2024 Purple Haze FRC. Contribute to lasarobotics/PH2024 development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
I think it would beneficial to conceive a method that does not rely on Pose.

A lot of teams start by learning the 2D method of aiming directly at a specific tag and doing a P loop by (tx * kP) for simple servoing to the target.

I would assume that simple method could be enhanced by a method that takes velocityX direction and distance into account to calculate a ‚Äúshot lag‚Äù factor to add/subtract in to the tx.

*Corrected to say shot lag instead of lead

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: You actually want to ‚Äúlag‚Äù the target so to speak, so that you cancel out the motion of the robot imparted onto the game piece. As in shoot ‚Äúbehind‚Äù where you normally would based on your current motion.
